Specific Details: We called on the current Government to develop a policy for credit unions that would allow and faciliate growth and development of services provided by the Sector.  This came on foot of serious ongoing concerns St Raphaels Garda Credit Union has regarding the current legislative environment and how damaging it is for the long term well being of credit unions in Ireland.   Our lobbying efforts included writing to our members seeking their support and asking them to contact their local TDs.
DPOs Lobbied: Mary Mitchell O'Connor|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Michael Noonan|Minister|Department of Finance::Joan Burton|Tánaiste and Minister|Department of Social Protection::Frances Fitzgerald|Minister|Department of Justice and Equality::Michael McGrath|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Robert Dowds|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Marian Harkin|MEP|European Parliament
Subject Matter: We called on the current Government to develop a policy for credit unions that would allow and faciliate growth and development of services provided by the Sector.  This came on foot of serious ongoing concerns St Raphaels Garda Credit Union has regarding the current legislative environment and how damaging it is for the long term well being of credit unions in Ireland.   Our lobbying efforts included writing to our members seeking their support and asking them to contact their local TDs.
Intended Results: A clear government policy that would set out the future positioning of credit unions in the context of the overall personal finance sector in Ireland.::Changes to the Credit Union and Cooperation with Overseas Regulators Act 2012::A review of the work of the commission report and the extent to which it has been implemented or not.::A tiered approach to regulation.::A review of the Personal Insolvency Legislation to explore anti-competitive concerns.::An industry lead forum to be established to explore the future development of the movement.::A removal of lending restrictions for credit unions.::A removal of the proposed savings cap of €100k as set out in CP88.::A review of longer term lending limits as set out in Section 35 of the Act.
Lobbying Activities: Letters were sent to various ministers and public representatives seeking a meeting to discuss our concerns and calling for their support.|Letter|6-10::Various meetings were held with public representatives seeking their support to raise the profile of policy related credit union issues for St Raphaels and other credit unions.|Meeting|6-10::Various emails were exchanged with public representatives outlining their stance on the issues raised by us, seeking clarification on our concerns, sharing of their responses received from Ministers, advising of proposed actions available to them and arranging meetings.|Email|21-30::Various phonecalls to follow up and arrange meetings.|Phone call|11-20
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Colm Church on Behalf of St Raphael's Garda Credit Union

Specific Details: Adressing the Societal Impact of Pain
Subject Matter: Adressing the Societal Impact of Pain
Intended Results: Support of the members of the European parliament for the symposium on the Societal Impact of Pain, May 23-24 Pain 2016
Lobbying Activities:
The symposium “Societal Impact of Pain” (SIP) 2016 took place on 23 May 2016 in the European Parliament. Over 220 representatives of health care- and stakeholder- organisations from more than 28 countries attended the Meeting co-hosted by MEP Marian Harkin (Ireland).
The scientific framework of the “Societal Impact of Pain” (SIP) platform is under the responsibility of the European Pain Federation EFIC®. Cooperation partners for SIP 2016 are Pain Alliance Europe (PAE) and Active Citizenship Network (ACN).The pharmaceutical company Grünenthal GmbH is responsible for funding and nonfinancial support (e.g. logistical support). The scientific aims of the SIP symposia have been endorsed by a large number of international and national pain advocacy groups, scientific organisations and authorities.
More info on SIP at: www.SIP-platform.eu|Meeting|1

Lobbying Activities: The European Pain Federation conducted this activity on behalf of the Partners of the Societal Impact of Pain Platform.  The 'Societal Impact of Pain' (SIP) is an international platform created in 2009 as a joint initiative of the European Pain Federation EFIC® and the pharmaceutical company Grünenthal GmbH.  The platform provides opportunities for discussion for health care professionals, pain advocacy groups, politicians, healthcare insurance providers, representatives of health authorities, regulators and budget holders. The scientific framework of the SIP platform is under the responsibility of the European Pain Federation EFIC®. Co-operation partners for SIP are Pain Alliance Europe and Active Citizenship Network. The pharmaceutical company Grünenthal GmbH is responsible for funding and non-financial support.|Email|2-5

Specific Details: Lifetime succession, land transfer and intergenerational renewal
Subject Matter: Lifetime succession, land transfer and intergenerational renewal
Intended Results: The rate of stamp duty on the transfer of agricultural land is charged at 7.5% (commercial rate) and IFA maintains that agricultural land should be reduced to the residential rate of 1%, up to €1m, and 2% thereafter. Consolidation relief and consanguinity relief are critical in reducing the stamp duty burden of transferring agricultural land.::Young Trained Farmer Stamp Duty Relief should be fully removed from State Aid or the ceiling of €70,000 (along with stock relief and succession partnership relief) be increased, to allow for greater land mobility, encourage land transfer and develop economically viable farm units. Furthermore, the age limit of 35 years should be moved in line with the Department of Agriculture's Young-Trained Farmer age maximum of 40 years and Revenue's age eligibility condition of the tax credit for successio::Under the Capital Acquisitions Tax (CAT) code, the Category A threshold (parent and child) should be increased from the current rate of €335,000 to €500,000 to support the transfer of economically viable family farms. Moreover, due to changing demographics and family structures, the Favourite Nephew or Niece Relief should be extended to a Favourite Successor Relief, allowing the farm to be gifted to someone who would be in a better position to continue farming the land.::If a landowner wishes to sell land to a long-term tenant, then the Capital Gains Tax (CGT) Entrepreneur relief of 10% will apply to incentivise supporting the genuine farmer and giving the long-term tenant preferred status. In addition, the lifetime limit of €1m on the CGT Entrepreneur relief should be increased in Budget 2021. The enhancement of CGT Entrepreneur Relief is an important measure to encourage risk-taking and investment, and the subsequent disposal of business assets during an ind::An individual should be able to avail, in full, of the CGT Entrepreneur Relief and the CGT Retirement Relief over the course of their lifetime. The interaction between the two CGT reliefs should be removed, and that the two reliefs should be standalone.::A robust and worthwhile retirement scheme would further encourage lifetime transfers.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Donal Sheehan IFA Farm Business Policy Executive

Specific Details: Deputies Harkin and McNamara held a briefing in Leinster House AV Room on the future of Nursing Homes in Ireland? They invited NHI and its members to speak at the briefing on what is happening on the ground in the sector and what needs to be done to support the sector and stop nursing homes from closing.
DPOs Lobbied: Marian Harkin|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Michael McNamara|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Deputies Harkin and McNamara held a briefing in Leinster House AV Room on the future of Nursing Homes in Ireland? They invited NHI and its members to speak at the briefing on what is happening on the ground in the sector and what needs to be done to support the sector and stop nursing homes from closing.
Intended Results: NHI and its members wanted to inform the parliamentarians of the current crisis in the sector and how the pressures the increasing costs were putting on the nursing homes and sustainability of the sector is in jeopardy and the government need to act now before it is too late and a policy for care of the older person must be devised by government as soon as possible.

Subject Matter: Met with Deputy McNamara and Deputy Harkin to keep them abreast of the developments within the private and voluntary nursing home sector and to inform them of the funding crisis that presents and the problems and closures that are arising from a lack of funding.
